pr_title: Fixed exceptions thrown for KeyVault's KeyClient.listPropertiesOfKeyVersions()

timeline.message: Fixed keyClient.listPropertiesOfKeyVersions() to throw a ResourceNotFoundException when a given key cannot be found. Also fixed the @throws section of its Javadoc.

timeline.bodyText:
Resource Not Found exception is used to indicate 404 response from the service.
if service doesn't throw 404, we should not alter it here as that will result in SDK overriding service behavior and will need to do it manually everywhere in an endless cycle.
rather change the javadocs to reflect the actual behavior and follow up with the service if this behaviour feels inconsistent or is a bug.
timeline.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: Thanks @g2vinay, I will talk to the service team about this then.
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText:
Before following up with the service, we should check the service response.
If they're already sending 404, then we need to properly map that in KeyService.class.
replies.author: g2vinay
vcolin7

replies.bodyText:
The stack trace posted on the linked issue above:
#11033
The issue says 404 is sent by the service.
replies.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: In this this comment I outlined how I could not get a 404 unless I send an empty or null key name, anything else returns 200, so unless there was a bug with the service at the time or they changed what the behavior is, the issue is not reproducible with a non-empty key name.
replies.author: vcolin7

timeline.message: Reverted changes on KeyAsyncClient. Changed KeyService's getKeyVersions() to return a ResourceNotFoundException when the service returns a response with status code 404. Changed KeyClient's javadoc to reflect this change.

timeline.bodyText:
This doesn't abide guidelines: https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_implementation.html#error-handling

The server error is not exposed, which is reuqired.
We shouldn't create derived types when the user has mitigation, like they can check for 404 themselves, which is what we do in other languages.

I think the documentation should be fixed instead of wrapping the service exception (which you're not currently doing anyway) in another one.
timeline.author: heaths

replies.bodyText: You can check my interpretation with architects.
replies.author: heaths

replies.bodyText:
Thanks for the feedback Heath! About the points you raise:


We do include the server error in both HttpResponseException and ResourceNotFoundException.


Both exceptions mentioned above are a part of azure-core for Java, so we would not be creating a new derived type, just using a different one that is more specific to the case. In any case, since there are not


I do agree the documentation should be fixed since it doesn't reflect current behavior.
One thing I'm not sure about, is the use of exceptions for server errors that are not specified in a service's swagger: in this case, it specifies that a successful response will only have a status code 200. Since the guidelines say that we should produce an error for all other cases, it seems ok to me to produce an exception like the ones I mentioned, we even do it for endpoints like /keys/{key-name}/backup where there is no specific mention of a 404 status code.
I will also be bringing this up with an architect like you suggested :)
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText: as per java guidelines, we should throw ResourceNotFoundException when service sends back 404.
replies.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: Should we then add this same exception to the other endpoints that don't have it?
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText: All these would be breaking changes, I assume, including this PR.
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText: Yes, this would be a breaking change. To note, we don't throw an exception for .NET, and I don't believe Python or TS do as well. I think the code needs to be left as-is and the documentation fixed to reflect reality.
replies.author: heaths

replies.bodyText:
This would not be a breaking change, I believe.
For 404, We currently throw HttpResponseException.
This change will throw ResourceNotFoundException which extends HttpResponseException.
replies.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: Except the discussion in the issue was about not returning a 404, but instead a 200 with an empty list. In what cases are you getting a 404 where you didn't during your investigation? If an empty list was returned before, and not you throw an exception - any exception - that is a breaking change.
replies.author: heaths

replies.bodyText: For example, .NET doesn't throw - it just gets an empty enumerable. Is that desirable? Probably not, but it's what the server returned to us. So I'm not even sure this fix would do anything since the service is not returning a 404 (proved with Postman earlier as well).
replies.author: heaths

replies.bodyText: JS and Python also return an empty list / don't throw. My point, though, is that if you're not already throwing - and it seems you wouldn't be, given the conversation Tuesday morning with @vcolin7 - this would be a breaking change. If you are already throwing, then since you derive the extension class that does seem fine to have something more specific.
replies.author: heaths

replies.bodyText:
So, my understanding of all this is:

Don't throw when we get a server response with an empty list and status code 200
It is ok to throw a more specific exception that extends from the one we already throw today.

Is this correct?
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText:
If the response is 200, we don't throw any exceptions currently and return the empty list already.
When we get 404, as the user reported issue #11033  mentions, we should throw the more specific exception.
replies.author: g2vinay

replies.bodyText: If they get a 404, yes, but @vcolin7 was unable to reproduce that. That said, I guess I don't see a harm in this as long as you're sure you're not throwing when an empty result is returned (i.e. 200).
replies.author: heaths

timeline.bodyText: we need to update KeyAsyncClient doc too.
timeline.author: g2vinay
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -757,8 +757,7 @@ public KeyVaultKey restoreKeyBackup(byte[] backup) {
      * @param name The name of the key.
      * @return {@link PagedIterable} of {@link KeyProperties key} of all the versions of the specified key in the vault. List
      *     is empty if key with {@code name} does not exist in key vault.
-     * @throws ResourceNotFoundException when a key with {@code name} doesn't exist in the key vault.
-     * @throws HttpResponseException when a key with {@code name} is empty string.
+     * @throws ResourceNotFoundException when a given key {@code name} is null or an empty string.
